image_1.description: Charlotte's Web is a detailed, intricate web attached to a vertical surface, likely a tree or post, where Charlotte hangs head-down to think and work on her plan to save Wilbur. It is central to her place of thinking and working.

Wilbur is a small pig with a curly tail, standing on its hind legs and looking up towards Charlotte's web. He expresses concern about his situation, engages in philosophical discussions with Charlotte about life and death, and is the focus of Charlotte's plan to save him from being killed.

image_2.description: Charlotte is a character who weaves complex, radial webs and engages in philosophical discussions with Wilbur, also promising to help him avoid death. She is a large spider that Avery wants to capture, but is protected by Fern and Wilbur.

A complex, radial web with multiple strands extending outward from the center where the spider Charlotte is located. It is Charlotte's place of thinking and working, where she hangs head-down to think, and it is central to her plan to save Wilbur.

image_3.description: Fern is a child who follows Avery into Zuckerman's yard, wearing a crown of daisies, helps with the frog crisis in the kitchen, and later enjoys swinging at Mr. Zuckerman's barn, showing concern for animals and trying to protect Charlotte the spider.

Mr. Zuckerman's Swing is a single long piece of heavy rope tied to the beam over the north doorway in Zuckerman's barn, known for being the best in the county, where Avery and Fern take turns swinging, enjoying the thrill of the activity.

Zuckerman's Barn is the location of many events in the story, including the best swing in the county, where Avery and Fern take turns swinging, and where Charlotte's web is located, impacting the fate of Wilbur.

The Pasture is a location where the children pick wild raspberries after growing tired of swinging, and where the animals, including sheep, lambs, gander, goose, and seven goslings, come from, complaining about the smell of the rotten egg.

image_4.description: A young boy with curly hair, wearing a striped shirt and shorts, lying on his back with his legs in the air, who is also known as Avery in the story and initially wants to capture a spider named Charlotte.

image_5.description: A detailed, intricate web with a central hub and radiating spokes, set against a dark background, where Charlotte, a spider, weaves messages that impact the fate of Wilbur, prominently displayed in the doorway of the barn cellar, right over the pigpen.

image_6.description: Zuckerman's Barn is a large wooden barn with a gabled roof and open doors, serving as the focal point of the gathering and the location where the spider's web with the message is found, above the pigpen.

A group of people standing in front of the barn, engaged in conversation and socializing, suggesting a community event which is also referred to as the local people who are affected by the miracle and visit the Zuckerman farm to see Wilbur.
Rolling hills in the background, providing a scenic backdrop to the event, and sparse trees scattered across the landscape, adding to the rural setting of Zuckerman's Farm.

image_8.description: Wilbur is a pig that is the center of attention due to the miracle on the Zuckerman farm. He is the pig whose life is in danger but is being saved by Charlotte's messages in her web. Wilbur is also described as feeling terrific and is the center of attention due to the messages in Charlotte's web.

The sheep are part of the animal community in the barn cellar, responding to Charlotte's roll call during the meeting. They are also a group of animals that participate in the meeting and contribute to the discussion about saving Wilbur. The lambs, the young sheep, also participate in the meeting and suggest slogans for Charlotte's web.

The ducks are gathered near the water, some are swimming and others are standing. They are also mentioned as a group of animals that participate in the meeting and suggest slogans for Charlotte's web.

image_9.description: Charlotte is a spider who weaves messages in her web and is an expert at it. She uses her eight legs and teeth to create a circular web with concentric circles and radial lines. Charlotte is responsible for writing messages in her web to save Wilbur's life, and she loves to weave.

The web is Charlotte's medium for writing messages that influence the perception of Wilbur and is central to the story. It is a circular web with concentric circles and radial lines, created by the spider. Charlotte uses different types of threads for foundation lines and snare lines to catch insects.

image_10.description: Wilbur is a pig who feels terrific and is the center of attention due to the messages in Charlotte's web. He is standing near a wooden post and a spider web.

The Web is Charlotte's medium for writing messages that influence the perception of Wilbur and is central to the story. It is a large spider web with the word 'TERRIFIC' woven into it, attached to a wooden post.

image_11.description: Templeton is a rat who scavenges the dump for useful items and interacts with Charlotte and Wilbur. He is also seen standing on his hind legs, appearing to be eating or interacting with a piece of bread that has the word 'CRUNCHY' written on it.

A piece of bread with the word 'CRUNCHY' written on it, being held by the rat Templeton, which is suggested as an advertising material for Charlotte's web but is rejected as it implies Wilbur's tastiness.

image_13.description: Charlotte is a character who communicates with Wilbur and Templeton, providing guidance and suggestions. She is also depicted as actively weaving a web over the water in the image, with her body detailed with segments and legs engaged in web construction.

The web is a structure built by Charlotte's cousin across a stream, where she caught a fish, as told in one of Charlotte's stories. It is also shown in the image as intricately drawn, spanning across the water and connecting to the grass on either side, in the process of being woven by the spider.

The stream is a geographical feature mentioned in the story where Charlotte's cousin built her web. It is also shown in the image as a calm body of water beneath the spider and its web, with ripples visible on the surface, indicating the disturbance caused by the spider's activity.

image_15.description: Dr. Dorian is a doctor with a thick beard, who Mrs. Arable consults for advice regarding Fern's behavior and provides insights on the miraculous nature of spiders' webs and animals' communication.

image_17.description: Wilbur is a large pig being petted by the woman and is also referred to as 'Zuckerman's Famous Pig'. He is being prepared for the County Fair by Mrs. Zuckerman, who gives him a buttermilk bath to clean him.

Mrs. Zuckerman is a character who decides to give Wilbur a buttermilk bath before the County Fair. She is also known as Edith and is actively involved in cleaning Wilbur, wearing rubber boots and an old raincoat for the task.
Mr. Zuckerman is a character who discusses Wilbur's cleanliness with Mrs. Zuckerman before the County Fair and takes pride in the cleanliness of his pig, Wilbur. He is also known as Homer.
